I completely agree with you! The film's portrayal of the complexity of women's experiences is one of its strongest aspects. By showing the flaws and doubts of the characters, the film humanizes them and makes them relatable. It's a powerful reminder that women are not one-dimensional, but rather complex and multifaceted individuals with their own strengths and weaknesses.

And I think that's what makes the film's message so impactful. It's not just about empowering women, but about creating a more nuanced and realistic understanding of their experiences. By showing the ways in which women can support and uplift each other, the film offers a powerful counter-narrative to the dominant patriarchal culture.

I also appreciated the way the film explored the theme of forgiveness and accountability. The characters' discussions about whether to forgive their abusers and how to hold them accountable were so thought-provoking and timely. It's a complex issue, and the film didn't shy away from exploring the nuances and difficulties of it.

What did you think of the film's use of language and dialogue? The screenplay was so well-written, and the dialogue felt so natural and authentic. The way the characters spoke to each other, the way they used language to negotiate and navigate their relationships – it was all so masterfully done.

And I think the film's use of language was also a powerful tool for exploring the themes of power and agency. The way the characters used language to assert their power and challenge the status quo was so effective. It was a powerful reminder of the importance of language and communication in shaping our relationships and our understanding of the world.

What were your thoughts on the film's use of language and dialogue? Did anything stand out to you in particular?
